pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:2.1: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:4.1: The sub-chapter on evenly all around
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:5.1: 1. The training rule on evenly all around
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:6.1: Venerables, these rules to be trained in come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:7.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:7.2: At that time the monks from the group of six wore their sarongs hanging down in front and behind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:7.4: “How could the Sakyan ascetics wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind? They are just like lay people who indulge in sensual pleasures.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:8.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:8.2: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:8.3: “How can the monks from the group of six wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.1: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Master.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.2: The Master then had the Order of monks assembled and questioned the monks from the group of six,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.3: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.6: Foolish men, how can you wear your sarongs hanging down in front and behind?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.7: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:9.8: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:10.1: ‘“I will wear the sarong evenly all around,” this is how you should train.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:11.1: One should wear the sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:11.2: If a monk, out of disrespect, wears the sarong hanging down in front or behind, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:12.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:13.1: The first training rule is finished.
